messageBody:
On 7/25/07, Békési Tibor <bekesi2002@...> wrote:
> As far as I know in JUnit 3 you could customize what to display in
> the JUnit view of Eclipse by overriding the getName() method of the
> TestCase. Is there any similar solution for that in JUnit 4?

A different set of design tradeoffs makes this difficult in JUnit 4.
in JUnit 3, you could ask each test case for its name, but that
required having all of the test case obects instantiated, which could
consume a lot of memory and start-up resources. In JUnit 4, the test
object does not exist until right before it runs, so it's up to a
Runner to statically determine the name of each test.

By the way, this is also the reason for the default naming in the
Parameterized runner. We wanted to be able to run on parameters that
were expensive to instantiate, or could only be traversed once,
without reverting to the "all work up front" model of JUnit 3. So we
only check the size of the parameter list when the methods are named.
It turns out that a lot of people are using lightweight parameters
like static String literals as their parameters, and, like you, have
no problem traversing the list multiple times. This accounts for
pretty much all the requests for renaming tests that I'm aware of.

> However, I would be interested in a solution that captures
> the "System.out" of my "testMethod[1]" separately from
> the "System.out" of my "testMethod[2]".

There is no built-in solution for this. When possible, I try to
include as much information as possible in my assertion failures, so
that I don't have to look at System.out to debug. When this isn't
possible, would it be enough to let each test know it's own name, so
you could print it to System.out? If so, check out this posting:

http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/18728

There should probably be a better way to do this in the future, but
I'm not aware of a current feature request for it. Thanks,

David Saff
